content: What I really mean't was I wanted life experience from the Army I joined because I wanted to be physically, mentally and emotionally pushed to my limits.I joined extremely excited, but when all my options seemed to be 25B, 25U I was extremely put off.I personally work well under pressure, wanted to see some combat fixing software isn't me.I tried to renegotiate my contract to be a 35M but now I'm stuck in 25B.I don't think this MOS plays well with my strengths and it will probably show some of my worst weaknesses.I'am almost completely computer illiterate, and if it wouldn't be for PT then I'd go nuts because I want to be outdoors as much as possible. I think I want to know if I could ever see combat?> or will I be sitting at a desk fixing computers all day? I need some feedback, thanks
reply: What I really mean't was I wanted life experience from the Army I joined because I wanted to be physically, mentally and emotionally pushed to my limits.I joined extremely excited, but when all my options seemed to be 25B, 25U I was extremely put off.I personally work well under pressure, wanted to see some combat fixing software isn't me.I tried to renegotiate my contract to be a 35M but now I'm stuck in 25B.I don't think this MOS plays well with my strengths and it will probably show some of my worst weaknesses.I'am almost completely computer illiterate, and if it wouldn't be for PT then I'd go nuts because I want to be outdoors as much as possible. I think I want to know if I could ever see combat?> or will I be sitting at a desk fixing computers all day? I need some feedback, thanks
title: 25B MOS, Is it challenging ?

content: You give some reference to being computer illiterate(or close to being) & yet you want to be, amongst other things mentally challenged. I take it this MOS has computer aspect to it, being semi-computer illiterate, won't this meet one of your challenges???

title: 25B MOS, Is it challenging ?

content: quote: Originally posted by KatrinaS: What I really mean't was I wanted life experience from the Army I joined because I wanted to be physically, mentally and emotionally pushed to my limits.I joined extremely excited, but when all my options seemed to be 25B, 25U I was extremely put off.I personally work well under pressure, wanted to see some combat fixing software isn't me.I tried to renegotiate my contract to be a 35M but now I'm stuck in 25B.I don't think this MOS plays well with my strengths and it will probably show some of my worst weaknesses.I'am almost completely computer illiterate, and if it wouldn't be for PT then I'd go nuts because I want to be outdoors as much as possible. I think I want to know if I could ever see combat?> or will I be sitting at a desk fixing computers all day? I need some feedback, thanks 25Bravo: Major Duties: The information systems operator-analyst supervises, installs, operates and performs unit level maintenance on multifunctional/multi-user information processing systems, peripheral equipment, and associated devices in mobile and fixed facilities; performs analyst functions; constructs, edits, and tests computer system programs; conducts data system studies and prepares documentation and specifications for proposals; operates and performs Preventive Maintenance Checks and Services (PMCS) on assigned vehicles and power generators. Duties for MOS 25B at each level of skill are: * Skill Levels o Skill Level 1 MOSC 25B1O. Installs, operates, and performs unit maintenance on multi-functional/multi-user information processing systems (radios and telephones, fixed and moblile) and peripheral equipment and auxiliary devices. Performs input/ output data control and bulk data storage operations (computers). Transfers data between information processing equipment and systems. Troubleshoots automation equipment and systems to the degree required for isolation of malfunctions to specific hardware or software. Restores equipment to operation by replacement of line replaceable unit (LRU). Installs, operates, performs strapping, restrapping, PMCS and unit level maintenance on COMSEC devices. Assists in the design, preparation, editing, and testing of computer programs. Drafts associated technical documentation for program reference and maintenance purposes. Modifies existing application packages using application and operating system software and appropriate computer language commands and files. In other words, you got to learn radios, telephones, computers, electronics in general - how to operate and how to fix all of the above in a VERY technical way - - Piece of cake - right? Wandering and Wondering

Duties for MOS 25B at each level of skill are: * Skill Levels o Skill Level 1 MOSC 25B1O. Installs, operates, and performs unit maintenance on multi-functional/multi-user information processing systems (radios and telephones, fixed and moblile) and peripheral equipment and auxiliary devices. Performs input/ output data control and bulk data storage operations (computers). Transfers data between information processing equipment and systems. Troubleshoots automation equipment and systems to the degree required for isolation of malfunctions to specific hardware or software. Restores equipment to operation by replacement of line replaceable unit (LRU). Installs, operates, performs strapping, restrapping, PMCS and unit level maintenance on COMSEC devices. Assists in the design, preparation, editing, and testing of computer programs. Drafts associated technical documentation for program reference and maintenance purposes. Modifies existing application packages using application and operating system software and appropriate computer language commands and files. In other words, you got to learn radios, telephones, computers, electronics in general - how to operate and how to fix all of the above in a VERY technical way - - Piece of cake - right? Wandering and Wondering
title: 25B MOS, Is it challenging ?

content: Moderator Hat Off! I enter the army in 1954 to be a combat engineer. Four years later I had an opportunity to changes MOS. I was tired old the rain, the cold and the mud – that was in peace time in Germany. I jumped at the MOS change. I spent two tours in Vietnam. The first six months of my first tour, 11/67-11/68, was as and SFC E7, MOS 74D40 (at that time it was Data Processing Operations NCO). On Tet 68 I spent seven hours in the Qui Nhon airport exchanging fire with a group of NVA and/or VC during which time one of the GIs in the airport was KIA and two others were WIA. I fired about 60 rounds from my M14. I don’t know idea if I hit anyone or not. Six months in to my first tour I was appointed a WO1 MOS 741A, at that time it was Data Processing Technician). Two soldiers who work directly for me were KIA, three others were WIA. My first assignment, in RVN after my WO1 appointment, I replaced a LT who was KIA just five days earlier. During the next six months another LT that I worked with KIA and two GIs in my section were medivaced WIA. On my second tour, 12/71-10/72, same MOS this time it was as a CW2. One GIs in my section was KIA. Two Korean civilians who worked for were killed. My two brothers both served in Korea and in Vietnam, one has a Bronze Star, Silver Star, two Purple hearts and a CIB (MOS 111) retired SFC. This brother told me when he went to Korea he wanted to be a hero, after the first night he just wanted to live long enough to go home in one piece. He is 50% disabled service connect combat related. The other brother has two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart (MOS 121) retired CSM 100% disabled all combat related. Male or female combat is not a place to find out if you’re up it. It is a place where men women and all too often child have arms and legs ripped off and many die. My last assignment in the army was still in data processing in Hawaii, ((25ht Infantry Division) 1976-77 as a CW3. My Operations Sergeant was John F. Baker who received the Medal of Honor in Vietnam he never thought working with computers was a step down. This morning my oldest daughter (USCG) and two of my granddaughters (her two daughters) )USCG and USAF) put on uniforms and did the job the military told them to do. That is what being a GI is all about. Thanks for wanting to serve. I sincerely hope your military service is as satisfying as mine was. Blessings to you and yours’ OAL Mod hat back on. God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

title: 25B MOS, Is it challenging ?

content: quote: In case I had forgot to mention it, thanks for your service to this great country. Your years of service shows your dedication to the people of this country and should never be taken lightly. I salute you sir (even if my date of rank was before yours LOL). Thanks, and back at you, chief. The two best warrants I ever knew, were CWO-W2 (old ludens bars**) Austin Longo, in 1955, he was every thing I ever wanted to be as a soldier and a warrant. His appointment came in 1941. He died about 15 years ago at 90-something. And my boss at the time of my appointment, CW2 Bill Johnston, he lives in Texas. We email each other about once a week. He was without a doubt the best systems programmer I've ever known. He had a CIB from Korea. Come to think of it I never saw either of those two men in anything but fatigues. WOPA God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: Thanks Chief. I also had a super mentor that I looked up to and whom talked me into getting my warrant. He was a Cw-4 in the Engineers by the name of Bill Roberts. Highly knowledgeable, hard at times but fair. Taught me a lot in the two years that I worked for him.
